Stock based compensations (SBCs) are a cost for investors. You should subtract SBCs from the free cash flow.

company_profile: Amazon.com, Inc. is an American multinational technology company focusing on e-commerce, cloud computing, online advertising, digital streaming, and artificial intelligence. Tweet: 8/Accept the unacceptable. Amzn stock doubled after I joined, but I was under water by my 1-year cliff. 3 yrs later I sold new RSUs at $8/share. In '08 I sold FB stock in a secondary transaction at $1/share to cover my rent in Palo Alto. Do what you need to do, never look back
company_profile: Amazon.com, Inc. is an American multinational technology company focusing on e-commerce, cloud computing, online advertising, digital streaming, and artificial intelligence. Amazon.com, Inc offers online retail, computing services, consumer electronics, digital content, and other local services such as daily deals and groceries. Headquartered in the United States

Tweet: 4/Change the tone. Amzn did a small but symbolic RIF in 2000. Around that time, Jeff was presented with a team t-shirt - he threw the team out of his office and banned all company swag. We even removed aspirin from the break rooms, served coffee and water. Small acts set the tone
company_profile: Amazon.com, Inc. is an American multinational technology company focusing on e-commerce, cloud computing, online advertising, digital streaming, and artificial intelligence. Amazon.com, Inc offers online retail, computing services, consumer electronics, digital content, and other local services such as daily deals and groceries. Headquartered in the United States

Tweet: 3/Growth can wait, survival cannot. Amzn‚Äôs stock price crossed $100 in '99 and bottomed at $6 in '01 (months from bankruptcy). We cut burn from >$1B to positive free cash flow by raising prices to stop the bleeding. Revenue growth slowed to 3% but we lived to fight another day
company_profile: Amazon.com, Inc. is an American multinational technology company focusing on e-commerce, cloud computing, online advertising, digital streaming, and artificial intelligence. Amazon.com, Inc offers online retail, computing services, consumer electronics, digital content, and other local services such as daily deals and groceries. Headquartered in the United States

Tweet: 1/Raise capital when you can, not when you need it. Amzn tapped convert debt in Feb '00 - if we had waited another month we would not have survived. 9 years later at FB we raised a 33% down-round despite having plenty of runway. Don‚Äôt wait until your back is up against the wall https://t.co/UlA1XsC5Kh

Here‚Äôs why I invest for returns, not income/dividends:

1. Not having to reinvest the income yourself saves on taxes and fees.

2. You benefit from the price-to-book ratio. If a company has a P/B ratio of 10 (e.g $AMZN), then $1 dollar of earnings retained as capital becomes $10. https://t.co/a9dXTsbIf9

-EV/EBITDA for high capex businesses (specifically $AMZN, $FB)
-EV/sales for structurally high or low margin businesses (high: $V, $ADBE, $TTD  or low: $UBER, $W)

Tweet: AMZN is actually proof of the opposite of what most people believe it is. If you have a very good business, it should be highly profitable from a very early stage, as have been GOOGL, FB, MSFT, AAPL. *All good businesses are high profitable while they grow*.
company_profile: Amazon.com, Inc. is an American multinational technology company focusing on e-commerce, cloud computing, online advertising, digital streaming, and artificial intelligence. Amazon.com, Inc offers online retail, computing services, consumer electronics, digital content, and other local services such as daily deals and groceries. Headquartered in the United States

Tweet: There is a profound irony with AMZN. It popularized the idea you should be willing to lose money to grow & invest through the P&L. But last year their e-com biz still lost US$2bn. Most of the value is in AWS, and that business has been monstrously profitable for a long time.

Tweet: L6: A company‚Äôs P/E is based on future expected growth rates, not comps in the category in which it competes. It‚Äôs why $TSLAQ PMs were wrong for years on AMZN (gave it a retail P/E), and now have been wrong on $TSLA (give it an auto P/E). This seems so basic, but they missed it.
